title: Rocket Boys and Rocket Girls - Is the dream a reality?
Good, Bad and Forgettable - Buffy Review
Vampires Are Just Sooo Dead
people: Stephen Dedman, Richard  Harland, Ian Irvine, Sue Isle

title: Sex and Evolution - The Evolution of Human Sexuality
Exiled to Earth: Dr. Who's 7th Season
people: David  Gunn, Heather  Macgee, Damian  Magee, Colin  Sharpe
description: A look at Jon Pertwee's first season as the Doctor.

title: Opening Ceremony
description: Shareholders are invited to join the Parasol Corporation Board for the official opening of Parasol's latest venture. What does the future hold for Parasol Corporation?

title: Welcome to Your First Con
description: Welcome to your first convention! Cons can be a magic space where awesome things happen, or you can end up hung over and/or dead on your feet. Come and find out where the toilets are, how to stave off starvation, and what to do when you have questions.

title: Parasites: What are you Carrying?
description: What ghastly, bloodsucking, skin-sisolving, genome corrupting, mind-controlling denizens of nightmare and hypchondria are you carryng **right now**?

title: Children's TV Shows: Live Action from the 60s and 70s
description: 1968-1984 is the golden time for live action series for most of the children of the world. This panel discusses some of these shows with clips including "Freewheelers", "Catweazle", "Ace of Wands", "Tomorrow People", "Andra" and many more. Come along and share your memories of those happy times.

title: LARP Presentation - Introduction
description: Live Action Role Playing - what is it, and what does it involve? Come and see.

title: Robin & Sidekicks in comics
description: Robin, Speedy, Bucky - what's the deal with heroes and sidekicks?

title: Scott Sigler - Guest of Honor Speech
description: This year's International Guest is let loose on an unsuspecting audience to show his first Australian convention what makes the man with the scissors tick.

title: Dark Fantasy
description: Examining an area of speculative fiction that has undergone substantial growth and popularity in recent times

title: Getting Published
description: Ian talks about the publishing marketplace, how it's changing, what publishers want and how to give it to them -- and what happens once you get an offer.

title: Aussiecon Promotion
description: Come and find out about the upcoming Worldcon being held in Melbourne

title: The Fleischer Brothers 'Superman'
description: For most of the 1940's, Superman cartoons are just a distant childhood memory but in fact technically and cinematically they were groundbreaking and helped to establish Superman as a multimedia franchise even becoming a propaganda tool for the allies.

title: Safe Spaces
people: Elaine  Kemp, Ju  LandÃ©esse, Sarah  Parker
description:
Everyone thinks of conventions as safe spaces where they can just hang out and be. This is not always true. Our panelists will talk about creating safe spaces, maintaining safe spaces, safe spaces at conventions and other public spaces, and the unspoken rules of safe spaces at cons. Includes discussions of the 
"Open Source Boob Project", room parties and conventions we've been to. There might be some amusing stories in there too as well as some warnings and food for thought.

title: Lost? The End is Near
people: Helen  Balfour, Tina  Eitelhuber, Tom  Eithelhuber
description: With the final season being well underway, Lost will soon be over! What have we learnt about the mysterious island since last year and what revelations could remain in store? As with 2009's panel, we'll be encouraging open discussion of the series to date as well as speculation on what might be in store for the show's final stretch. A must for all Lost fans!

title: Perfectly Packaged - Designing Science Fiction
description: So the novel has been written and edited - but what governs how the final product will look? How do science fiction and fantasy books get covers, who determines their perfect audience and how do publishers and distributors go about the task of selling as many copies as possible? What works, what doesn't and what are the trends of the present and the future?

title: Disability in Science Fiction
description: Monsters, mutants and mundanes: some of the common tropes and interesting possibilites around the portrayal of disability in science fiction.

title: The Future of Television - Does it have a future?
description: With everyone downloading of buying shows on DVD, has television lost its way or has it made its run?

title: Getting to Know Narelle
description: Narelle reads from her novel "The Opposite of Life"; a vampire novel based in contemporary Melbourne. Find out why Charlaine Harris (author of the Sookie Stackhouse novels) says, "If you can get this book, do".

title: Auction
people: Chris  Creagh, Helen  Creagh, Anna  Hepworth
description: Come one, come all! The Swancon Auction will be the place to peruse and purchase the fabled fabric of fandom. Perhaps the presence of previously possessed paraphernalia will pry your purses of pennies? Or the phonics of fair Helen will facilitate the hammer-fall on a farrago of fashionable finds and fortune the ferrying of funds. **If you have beautiful things that you wish to sell please register then in the reception area after 6:30pm on Thursday and before 6:30 on Friday.**

title: Making the Magic in Fantasy Novels work
people: Stephen Dedman, Richard  Harland, Sonia  Hebig, Sarah  Parker, Carol  Ryles
description: Our panelists have completed a number of works which feature magic in fantasy worlds. How do they balance the ned for the magic to 'work' while within the creative writing structure? Have there ever been instances when the magic hasn't worked, and had to be fixed in a work in progress? How can you tell when it's not working? Are there times when the nature of the magic in the worlds hasn't worked in a creative or holistic way with the plot?

title: Andy Warhol and Fan Re-mixing
description: Two of they key ideas informing Warhol's art are repetition and transformation, particularly in regards to the icons of everyday culture. I became interested in this philosophy because these ideas also underpin the remixing undertaken by many fans when creating fanworks. In this session, discussion will take place on some early discoveries about Warhol's work and philosophy and how they parallel the practices of current fan remixers and inform the wider practices of remix culture.

title: Sandbox Vs Theme Park: MMOs Types
description: Some MMOs are like "Theme Parks" in that there are attractions fo play through and a fairly set path to progress. In others, progression is what you make of it. Which ones work best for what kind of person and why do we like them?

title: The Iron Brain Competition
description: There are good stores, great novels and truly awful writing. And there is writing of that "special" sort that makes you giggle in horror. Can you last through the reading without cracking a grin? Bring your 'terrible texts' along (of any rating) and test your strength of will. Guest starring the infamous "Eye or Aragon" by Jim Theis **This panel is an 18+ event and ID checks WILL be enforced**

title: Scary Kisses Anthology
description: This is a launch fo the locally produced anthology _Scary Kisses_

title: No you can't have a f... flying car; You couldn't get it to the market and it wouldn't sell anyway!
description: Making a scientific discovery or inventing something is only half the battle. How do you move from the discovery phase to actually making a practical -- even commercial -- application? What makes the difference between commercial viable science and an interesting novelty? A look into the science and technology of the future, how they come to the market, why they succeed -- and the scientific discoveries guaranteed to fall?

title: The New Who
people: Micheal  Cogan, Aaron  Creaser, Narelle Harris, Damian  Magee
description: An in-depth look at the changes from the David Tennant era to the Matt Smith era. This will include a look at the cast and crew changes and the previous work of Matt Smith and Karen Gillian.

title: Guest of Honour Reading
description: Ian will read a piece of prose of his choosing.

title: Haven't a Thing to Wear
description: The Masquerade Ball is tonight; are you dressing up? Have you got a costume, or is your costume giving you trouble? Come and get help fixing it, kludging one together for fun or just finishing it off in good company. Bring your bits and pieces to add to ours. Supervised school aged children welcome, but please, no glitter!

title: Gynaecon 10th Anniversary
description: Join in the celebration of Gynaecon's 10th Anniversary, as we look back at what has been and where we are going. Find out about the Norma Hemming Award to be presented for the first time at Aussiecon 4 in September. There will be cake!

title: What's New and Notable in Child and Young Adult Sci-Fi and Fantasy
description: Looking for some good reads for kids and teenagers? Gina will review recent and upcoming releases in the field and unearth some gems yu might not have heard of yet. Spend some time in the prison of _Incarceron_, fly with a _Mockingjay_, take a ride on _Leviathan_ or find out what happens _When You Reach Me_.

title: Ian Irvine - Guest of Honour Speech
description: Come and see our Australian Guest of Honor impart his knowledge and insight.

title: Xena - A Retrospective View
description: Xena: Warrior Princess was a huge phenomenon, bigger even than the original show _Hercules: The Legendary Journeys_ that spawned it. What caused people to sit up and take notices, where are the stars now and what messages and themes were important in such a culturally fascinating TV series?

title: The Blockbusters of Shame
description: Who are the writers of science fiction and fantasy we don't embrase? Some of the world's best selling authors write SF, fantasy or speculative literature and yet we, in fandom, don't include them as part of the tribe. On the other hand, who are the writers who we wish would come into the fold but reject our loving embraces? How do once popular writers become unfashionable? Your panelists will look at the shame and snobbery surrounding science fiction and fantasy publishing and fannish enthusiasms.

title: Rumble in the Prose
people: Wing Chung, Kaneda   Cruz, Stephen Dedman, Scott  Sigler
description: Pit your writing skills with professional authors in an interactive panel that tests your skills in writing exciting, evocative and entertaining fight scenes. Kaneda and Wing will provide short fight vignettes as the inspiration and basis for volunteers to write a fight scene. The professional authors and audience volunteers will then have 5 minutes to come up with a piece of prose as though it were a pivotal fight scene in a novel, short story or epic poem. The audience is the referee and decides the winner. Will it be you? There is also time to discuss what makes it easy or hard to write fight scenes and our professional authors can provide hints and tips as well. So bring your pens, pencils, pads, notebooks, netbooks, iPads and imagination and show us that you can be a literary warrior.

title: NASA's Budget Proposal
people: John  Parker, Paul  Talbot, Andrew Williams
description: NASA has just announced dramatic changes in the future of space exploration after a White House committee found that NASA's current plans were largely unachievable without massive funding increases. The new budget cancels essentially all NASA human space programs, largely outsources human space exploration to private companies and allows NASA to focus on basic R&D and robotic exploration. These changes generated huge controversy, and the panel will cover the budget, and the issues, in detail.

title: Modernising Classic Horror
people: John  Parker, Andrew  Sharp, Mike  Sharp, Kendra  Swaine

title: Dust, frogs, and the Square Kilometre Array - Whats going on now  onsite in the Murchison Region
description: Southern Africa and Australia are still competing to host the proposed 'Square Kilometer Array' (SKA), a radio telescope that will be more powerful than every other radio telescope in the world combined. The site decision won't be made until 2012 but smaller telescopes are being built at both of the proposed sites already. Dr Williams has been working on one of theme - the 'Murchison Widefield Array' (MWA) telescope project -- since 2007, and will tak about the MWA, other radio telescopes being built at the Australian site, and what it's actually like to work at the Australian SKA site.

title: Comics You Should Be Reading
description: Our panel of avid comics readers will give you a guided tour of some of their favorite current titles. If you're looking for recommendations then look no further!

title: LARP Makeup Presentation
description: Learn how makeup can improve your LARPing experience.

title: Masquerade
description: And down in the depths of darkness you will find... _THE MONSTER MASH!_ Come along and shake your groove "THING...S"

title: An Introduction to Vlad Taltos
description: Steve Burst has written 12 novels starring Vlad Taltos. Come along and learn of Vlad and the world of Dragaera, a world in which the human VLAD lives amongst the elves and the trouble this gets him in.

title: Dating the Undead
description: With all this paranormal romance around, isn't it time we examined the whole dating the undead phenomenon in detail? What are the pitfalls of dating someone who has already shuffled off this mortal coil? Do vampires, zombies or mummies make the best partners?

title: Future War - Vision of Neuromancer
description:
We live in a highly connected world as a result of the internet. Conputing and telecommunications are a ubiquitous part of our lives that impact our social networks, financial systems, critical infrastructure such as power, water, social networks, financial systems and telecommunications. Technology has improved to the extent that we have small wireless computers, commercially available neural interfaces (Project Epoc Headsets from Emotive Systems) and Motion Control (wii) devices. Moreover, private enterprise (e.g. Commonwealth Bank) is seeking to reduce it's total cost of ownership for its computing and telecommunications by buying it as a service via cloud computing (e.g. Google, Microsoft). The UK Government is setting up its own internal cloud computing service for government agencies with an anticipated saving of Â£3.2 billion annually. There are those that will seek to take advantage of the ubiquity and concentration of technology to carry out their criminal, political and economic agendas. We have seen large scale cyber attacks to governments in Georgia and Estonia via botnets, floods etc. and government have seen that there are credible threats to cyberspace and their national security and have set up internal groups in their military to carry out and defend against cyberattacks, funded cross boundary exercises (Cyberstorm I, II and III), established national fora (IMPACT) to address these threats.

This panel discusses from an Australian context weather the SF visions of cyber war, espionage and terrorism are becoming a reality. What are the targets and could current practises/technologies stop them or at least limit the damage? What impact would it have on society and would we notice anything different?

title: Avatar -Where do we go from here?
description: Is James Cameron's visual spectacular a sign of things to come? Will all SF and fantasy movies end up being made in 3D? Does AVATAR represent the logical conclusion of our craving for "Wonder" ? What does this mean for story? And, er, what about the characters?

title: Yoga
description: Writers spend a lot of time in front of a screen and often forget to exercise. What's more, many envision a yoga class as being a cross between a book camp and a contortionist's convention, so they don't even try it. In this gentle class we shall explore ways of using walls, desks and chairs as props and supports to get you moving, even if you are, like me, unfit, overweight, and overstressed and over 40.

title: 2009 in film
description: Reboots of classis franchises, adaptions of old fan favourites, re-imaginings of 80s cartoon classics, fantastical imaginary worlds, thrilling horror, eye-popping animation, sequesls galore and some tall blue aliens that made James Cameron (even more) exceedingly wealthy. We present the films which defined geek cinema for the year 2009 and try to separate the hits from the misses.

title: How did they do that?
description: We've seen some spectacular costumes over the years, many memorable for beauty, shock or sheer niftiness. Ever wondered how they got those wings to stick, or how they made that cool beeping noise? Find out our secrets and revisit costumes you may have never seen!

title: Guest of Honour Reading
description: Scott will read a piece of prose of his choosing.

title: Looking back at classic children's sci-fi & Fantasy Literature
description: Looking back on classic children's Sci-Fi/Fantasy; such as the Tripods series, The Neverending Story, books by Madeline L'Engle, C.S. Lewis, Edith Nasbit, Andre Norton, Terry Prachett, Patricia Wrightson and many, many more. Bring your own memories of what you read.

title: Girl Genius
description: Phil and Kaja Folio's _Girl Genius_ is a popular physical AND web comic based on a "Gaslight Fantasy" universe filled with monsters, steam powered robots and mad scientists. Come and hear the panelists try and predict the future of the series, as well as a compare the current tangled skein of plots.

title: Editing... How it Works
people: Gina  Goddard, Narelle Harris, Anna  Hepworth
description: Some times all a book needs to be great -- is a good edit!

title: Rock Star
description: Want to be a Rock Star, but don't have time of talent? Looking for alternate ways to get your Real Band heard? A look a music console games and how they can affect the appreciation, acceptance, promotion and training of many of today's music and tomorrow's musicians.

title: World War II and Alternative Histories
people: John  Parker, Andrew  Sharp, Mike  Sharp

title: Sue and Gina's Excellent... Adventure
description: Party on with tales from Sue and Gina!

title: Astroboy: New Century, New Visions
description: In 2009, Osamu Tezuka's Astroboy (aka Testuwan Atom) was adapted as both an American-funded CGI motion picture and as an eight-volume manga, Pluto by Naoki Urasawa. What is the continuing appeal of the Astroboy character, what new angles did the film and manga discover and how effectively did they contribute to the legacy of anime's most beloved character?

title: Geek Away
description: Come on a journey with Desiree and Owen as they explore Geek Japan, Godzilla and Otaku and Totoro -- oh my!

title: Torchwood: Exposed!
description: An examination of the Doctor Who spin-off.

title: The Best and Worst of Anime
description: Like any genre, Anime has it's highs and lows. Come discuss them here.

title: Fiction of Anthropomorphic Animals
description: Come on a journey with Anna and Desiree into the use of anthropomorphic animals in fiction.

title: Inside the Sci fi B-Movie
description: Weather a solid pulp or a guilty pleasure, the B-movie has been a staple of science fiction, fantasy and horror cinema since the 1950s. What makes a good B-Movie? Where is the line that divides the cool and culty from the bad or the unwatchable? From the famous B-Movies of the 1950s to the direct-to-DVD flicks of today, we present a special guide to the filmmakers, the trends and the individual films that every B-fan should be watching.

title: Rebel Empire Lightsaber Workshop: Stage Combat with a Twist
description: Learn basic tricks and techniques used by Jedi and Sith. Learn basic Fight Choreography techniques used by the pros. All the fun and drama you've watched in the movies for Years. Dress up and put yourself in the world of Star Wars! Those who wish to bring their own lightsabres are encouraged. Places are limited and registration at the front desk is required prior to the workshop.

title: Promoting Your Book
description: Books don't sell themselves and often publishers don't try hard to sell them either. Ian tells you what you need to know to make your book a success - and all the things that have done that have failed!

title: How About Heinlein?
people: Gina  Goddard, Emma  Hawkes, John  Samuel
description: Robert Heinlein's reputation has take a few hits since his heyday, but the influence of his works, particularly his juvenile novels cannot be understated. Three readers take a look at how Heinlein's juveniles stand up today and consider what they have to offer the 21st century reader.

title: Steampunk: The word on everyone's lips
description: Why has the Steam Age come back into our collective imagination? What's the appeal? Why now? Where does it come from? And where is it steaming to? Is it a passing fad or a real challenge to the established set-up of spec fic genres? Is it mostly a style of fiction or mostly a style of dress? Could it be a whole way of life?

title: Swancon 2011 Launch
description: Come and see what surprises 2011 has in store for you...

title: Awards Ceremony
description: Wherein the winners of the Tin Ducks and other awards are announced.

title: Video Quiz
description: For the fourth year, come and join in the fun and test your powers of observation by watching snippet clips from film & TV and try to answer those questions.

title: Sing Star Idol
description: Swancon's own karaoke competition! Prizes for best score and audience's choice. Signup sheet at registration desk.

title: Top SF&F Movies of the decade
description: The noughties are over! With the first decade of the new millenium behind us, the SwanCon community has voted to determine its 20 favorite films of 2000-09. Come along and see the results! If you haven't voted yet, it isn't too late -- grab a form from the registration desk and cast your vote by 4PM Saturday 3rd April.

title: Anime Archetypes
description: John discusses the many character archetypes that can be found amongst anime.

title: Lets Go Fangirling!
description: In a competition panel lat year's 'Fine Fellows of (Spec) Fiction", Helen, Desiree and the audience will put favourite (and not so favourite) female characters from TV and film through the 'Shag/ Marry/ Cliff' game -- now with new added category... BEER!

title: Star Trek: Chat Time
description: Join us to passionately (but politely) discuss how well the latest Star Trek movie lived up to its source material and what it means for the future of the franchise. Bring your pointy ears!

title: Rats! Foiled Again
description: In honour of the convention's infectious theme, a simple introduction to the natural history, mythology and literature of rats, mice and the many, many deadly diseases they're infecting you with.

title: Project Runway: Swancon
description: Horses and fins and heels... oh my a look at non biodegradable fashion, present and future.

title: American Spaceflight: Where to Next?
description: A look at recent decisions that leave uncertainty surrounding the direction that American space flight will take.

title: Looking back at the X-Files
description: What went wrong during the later series that made it unwatchable? This panel looks back on the best of the series and the worst. Is it a series to look at again, or just a series for its time?

title: The art of telling a story in speculative fiction
description: Fantasy, Science Fiction and Horror not only demand more imagination than other genres, but a very high level of narrative technique. When there's no real world to fall back on, everything has to work perfectly and plausibly to keep disbelief suspended and carry the reader along. Richard talks of some of the basics: story-arcs and character-arcs; 'defining' a mystery; building to a climax; sequencing (the right events in the best order); maintaining momentum and writing effective action scenes.

title: Making Science Work in Your SF Novel
people: Stephanie   Bateman-Graham, Stephen Dedman, Carol  Ryles, Scott  Sigler
description: Science fiction is a strange beast in that it has a relationship to both real and imaginary worlds. The relationship can be tenuous at best but it has to be there. Our panellists will discuss the science in their works, how they make it work and what's important when trying to balance the science and story in a novel.

title: SFF and Romance
people: Elaine  Kemp, Juliet  Marillier, Samara  Morgan, Sarah  Parker
description: A discussion of romance within science fiction and fantasy

title: Closing Ceremony
description: And now the end is near.. we face the final curtain. The fun has been had, the baton has been passed.

title: A Touch of The Strange - Theodore Sturgeon
description: The neglected giant of the Golden Age, renowned for his work in SF horror, westerns, Star Trek and more. A writer of such lyrical talent that the fans still rave about his work 70 years after some of them were written but equally notorious for his years of writer's block and his private life.

title: Swancon 2011 Homework
description: Hear more suggestions about the 2011 Swancon guests and their work, and get some reading suggestions from the 2011 committee to prepare for next year's Swancon.

title: Book Reading
description: Narelle will read a piece of prose of her choosing.

title: World Without End
description:
Aging is not simply the accumulation of years; it is also the accumulation of experience. It is something of a homily to insist that those who are older differ from those who are younger in ways which are not only physical, but it seems an inevitable conclusion of observation. As people live longer, healthier lives, is this difference exacerbated? What if people's lives were enormously extended, even indefinitely extended? 

Join Ian to discuss the concept of extended lifespan and immortality in the modern speculative fiction genre.

title: Saints and Griefers: Gamers Psychology
description: MMO addicts, Halo fanboys, Bejewelled slaves -- what makes us games enthusiasts? Is it a sad addiction, or moulding a better tomorrow? A look at the differences and similarities between game genres and those who play them, the evolutionary trends of gaming and how to build a community around gaming.

title: Words of Women
people: Gina  Goddard, Helen   Merrick, Sarah  Parker
description: Join our panellists in recommending works of female science fiction and fantasy writers. What gems have you been missing? All recommendations welcome.

title: Stephen King Film Adaptations
description: Join Scott as he takes a look at Stephen King's filmography, comparing some of the movies to the books that spawned them. He'll discuss which ones are (in his opinion) the successes, poke the "failures" to analyse what might have saved them and considers which books he'd love to see make it to the big screen.

title: Whats on Television This Year?
description: A look into the new and upcoming television shows of 2010: what are the ones to look out for, which ones should be avoided -- and what predictions for 2009 did Jenny and Graeme get right?

title: 10 Reasons we should legalise Human Cloning
people: Linda  Deegan, John   Green, Richard  Harland
description: The debate rages on weather human cloning should be legalised or not with controversy surrounding issues such as stem cell research. Should human cloning be legalised? What reasons would be acceptable? What if we want the power to take over the world?

title: Anyone can write a thousand page novel, it's writing short stories that's difficult!
people: Stephen Dedman, Richard  Harland, Ian Irvine, Sue Isle
description: Some writers say it's easy to write a short story that you can think up in a single stroke of inspiration and knock off in an afternoon. Others say it's easy to write a baggy fantasy epic where you can ramble off into whatever takes your fancy for as long as you please. But what about all the tightening, sharpening and revising when every word has to count in a short story? On the other hand, what about all the baggy monsters that flounder and sag and never get finished because the writer can't keep a complex plot under control? Are there two types of author? What ferocious injuries will they inflict on each other when you put them all on a panel together?

title: So young and hot!
description: Once upon a time, YA SF and fantasy was just a derivative, watered-down version of adult SF and fantasy. Now everyone wants to write it and it's the source of all the hottest new ideas. Think Philip Pullman, Garth Nix, Jonathan Stroud, Phillip Reeve and many more. Our panelists discuss the whys and wherefores.

title: Safe LARP Combat
description: What makes for safe LARPing? Come and find out.
